awd_titl_txt: CRII: CHS: Understanding and Supporting the Use of Self-Driving Vehicles by Persons with Visual Disabilities
awd_abstract_narration:
The emergence of fully autonomous or "self-driving" vehicles may prove to be the most significant evolution in personal mobility of the past century. It is envisioned that the most advanced of such vehicles will operate with minimal human interaction and no direct human driving. By minimizing the role of often error-prone human beings in the driving process, vehicle crashes may be reduced significantly, thus saving tens of thousands of lives annually and untold millions of dollars in property.  While this technology is potentially ground breaking for society broadly, self-driving vehicles may prove especially beneficial for those who are blind or who cannot otherwise operate conventional motor vehicles due to their disability. Despite the tremendous promise of self-driving technology in this regard, advocates of the many blind and visually impaired persons in the United States argue that the needs of visually impaired persons are not being adequately considered in the design of the technology, resulting in what may become accessibility barriers to its use. The PI seeks to address this issue through research that will explore the potential accessibility barriers encountered by visually impaired persons in their practical use of a self-driving vehicle, and through fundamental research that will derive solutions to these problems.  

The goal of this project is to produce a model of interaction that will support the use of self-driving vehicle technology by visually impaired persons. Following a user-centered inclusive design process the research will specifically seek to understand: (a) how self-driving vehicle human-machine interfaces are presently implemented in experimental vehicles; (b) how visually impaired persons envision their interactions with self-driving vehicles; (c) what accessibility challenges are faced by visually impaired persons in related Transportation-as-a-Service technologies; and (d) what types of novel self-driving vehicle user interfaces, interaction modalities and tools can be developed to support optimal usability and accessibility for visually impaired persons. The project will culminate with evaluation of accessible self-driving vehicle interface prototypes developed in participatory design sessions.  Project outcomes will further the understanding of auditory, kinesthetic, tangible and affective interfaces through the development of techniques and tools to support human-machine interaction that is primarily non-visual in nature.  The project will also further science regarding underlying processes that support accessible and universal design.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The emergence of fully autonomous or “self-driving” vehicles (SDVs) may prove to be the biggest evolution in personal mobility of the past century. Though promising, many disability advocacy groups contend that much of this technology is being designed without appropriate consideration for accessibility. This research project was undertaken to: 1) explore the needs, preferences, and concerns of users with visual disabilities specifically regarding SDVs, 2) develop a model of human-SDV interaction that supports the diverse needs of users with visual disabilities, 3) develop novel user interfaces and tools that support SDV users with visual disabilities, and 4) to evaluate these tools in a conceptual SDV usage scenario.

To explore this topic, we leveraged a user-centered research and design approach focused on providing a multifaceted perspective on the problem of SDV accessibility. This research has yielded significant results in several key areas:

Firstly, we found that SDV human-machine interfaces (HMI) and related interaction technologies may need to be conversational. Given that it is anticipated that users will initially encounter SDVs first via ridesharing services, we conducted a scenario-based quasi-naturalistic study to understand how blind and low vision users experience popular ridesharing services in the United States. We found that participants in the study worked towards building trust in the driver and the service through simple conversations with ride-sharing drivers and that these conversations were key to participants' sense of personal safety. This finding provides insight into the likely artificial intelligence-based conversational capabilities needed in an SDV HMI in the absence of a human driver.

Secondly, we found that a novel participatory design process, user enactment, may be an effective methodological tool to explore the design of accessible SDVs. There are a limited number of design techniques described within the scientific literature which are intended to directly support the ability of older adults and persons with disabilities to imagine interaction with non-existent technologies. While participatory design is one such technique, this approach may be limited in circumstances where participants have little a priori knowledge of the technology under design or where such a technology is wholly different from what has come before. User enactment, based on the concept of body storming, is a design technique that has been discussed in the SDV ideation context but has not been previously explored as a tool to aid persons with disabilities and older adults in the ideation process. We conducted a series of user enactment sessions with older adults and participants with and without disabilities to explore the use of user enactment in SDV design. We found that the process was effective in helping participants conceptualize interaction with an SDV and we have developed what we call Inclusive Metaphor-Based User Enactment which uses metaphors and principles of inclusivity to support the design of accessible and assistive technologies. 

Thirdly, we developed an interaction model tailored toward the specific needs of transportation users with disabilities. While there are many models of human activity that describe the use of assistive technology, we argue that existing and popularly used models like the Human Activity Assistive Technology model (HAAT) are insufficient tools to support the design and development of accessible self-driving vehicles. We propose a more context-specific model which we call the User Transportation-Activity and Technology Model (UTT). The model consists of three main components, all of which lie within the context in which the user will use technology to perform the transportation activity. We leveraged this model within the research project to conceptualize accessible SDV HMI.

Lastly, we found through our design activities that a single “universally accessible” SDV HMI may fall short of the specific and often distinct accessibility needs of users with disabilities. Through a user-centered design process we have explored digital interface adaptation or the design/development of responsive digital interfaces that adapt to the specific needs of individual users. Our initial prototype ecosystem consists of a user-facing mobile application, a machine learning model deployed to the cloud, and the "adaptive" SDV human-machine interface. Our intent with this innovation is to provide consumers with a cloud-based system that leverages the predictive power of Artificial Intelligence to adapt, in real-time, digital automotive interfaces to the specific needs and preferences of users with disabilities.

Our findings directly support the development of self-driving vehicles that are more broadly accessible for an ageing and ability-diverse population. 

In conclusion, the research conducted to understand the needs, preferences, and concerns of persons with visual disabilities on self-driving vehicles has yielded significant results at the intersection of inclusive design, software engineering, and human-centered artificial intelligence. Fundamentally, the conceptualization and design of an adaptive SDV human-machine interface provides a new use case for adaptive interfaces and lays the foundation for future work.
